AttributeValuesData.AttributeValue: evergreen known for its dark green color and dense, conical form
1/3”-3/4” long needles individually attached; color varies from dark green to blue-green
ash-brown or gray with flaky scales
female color ranges from green to purple; male colors are tannish to pale red
1-2” long cones are slender, tan-brown; appear in midsummer and drop in late fall

The Black Hills Spruce is a variety of White Spruce native to the Black Hills of South Dakota. It has a dense, more compact shape than the White Spruce and grows slower. In addition, the cones of the Black Hills Spruce are shorter and heavier than those of the White Spruce. Perhaps due to challenging growing conditions in South Dakota, Black Hills Spruce trees are very cold resistant and tolerant of the drying winter winds. As a result, the Black Hills Spruce makes an ideal, hardy windbreak or privacy screen. It can also be used effectively in group plantings or as a single ornamental tree. Black Hills Spruce trees usually require very little pruning because of their dense, slow growth. This variety of spruce has few bothersome pests. While it prefers rich, moist soil in full sun, the Black Hills Spruce will adapt to dry, well-drained conditions. It is, however, sensitive to soil compaction. The state tree of South Dakota since 1947, the Black Hills Spruce is a long-lived tree with a life span of more than 150 years. One of the national champion Black Hills Spruce trees measured 96 feet tall and is growing in Bear Butte Creek, South Dakota. The Lakota Indians referred to the spruce as the “wazi heaka” which means “like pine.” The Plains Indians had a number of uses for the Black Hills Spruce. They used the inner bark and shoots for food. Hardened sap from the tree was chewed as a form of gum. The spruce wood was collected and used for tipi poles. The wood of spruce trees grown and harvested in the United States is exported to Japan, where it is known as “shin-kaya.” There it is used as a board substitute for the rare Kaya wood. These beautiful evergreen conifers are showcased at WSU’s West Campus of Lourdes Hall. There, in the central courtyard, a grouping of five Black Hills Spruce are thriving on two separate sites. One is located on a small berm south of the main sidewalk, while the other is found on a small hill on the north side of the sidewalk. A third planting is growing on the south side of Lourdes Hall.
